channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Last respects paid to Lady Thatcher
item.description: The Bishop of London leads prayers at St Paul's Cathedral in London as the Queen and more than 2,000 dignitaries pay their last respects to the former UK prime minster at her funeral.

item.title: Pressure cooker clues to Boston bomb
item.description: FBI images show a backpack and apparent fragments of a pressure cooker as it probes the attack on the Boston Marathon that left three dead.

item.title: Abu Qatada: Home Office seeks appeal
item.description: The Home Office asks for permission to appeal to the Supreme Court against a ruling preventing the deportation of radical cleric Abu Qatada.

item.title: Tesco's exit from US to cost £1.2bn
item.description: Tesco's annual profits fall for the first time in almost 20 years as the UK's biggest supermarket confirms it is pulling out of the US.

item.title: UK unemployment up to 2.56 million
item.description: Unemployment rose by 70,000 to 2.56 million between December and February, the Office for National Statistics says.

item.title: New Zealand legalises gay marriage
item.description: New Zealand's parliament legalises same-sex marriage, making it the first country in the Asia-Pacific region to do so.

item.title: 'Ricin' in letter to US senator
item.description: A letter with a Memphis postmark sent to US Republican senator Roger Wicker tests positive for the poison ricin, the Senate majority leader says.

item.title: Alps crash Britons kept in hospital
item.description: Three Britons seriously hurt in a coach crash in which the UK driver died remain in a hospital in the French Alps.

item.title: MMR campaign targets 2,000 pupils
item.description: A targeted MMR vaccination campaign starts among more than 2,000 pupils at five comprehensives in Swansea and Neath Port Talbot.

item.title: Judges quash child murder conviction
item.description: A mother who was jailed for life for murdering her toddler son has had her conviction quashed on appeal.

item.title: Woman dead and five injured in fire
item.description: A woman dies, a 16-year-old girl is critically injured and four others are hurt in a house fire in Birmingham.

item.title: Light drinking 'not harmful to baby'
item.description: Light drinking during pregnancy does not harm child behavioural or mental development, a study reports.

item.title: Beckhams are 'posher', study finds
item.description: David and Victoria Beckham have changed their speech to "sound less working class", researchers at the University of Manchester conclude.

item.title: Gov.uk website wins design award
item.description: The UK government's Gov.uk website is described as the "Paul Smith of websites" as it picks up the prestigious Design of the Year award.

item.title: Promotion reduces Bellamy to tears
item.description: Cardiff striker Craig Bellamy says winning promotion with his home town club will 'live with me for years'.

item.title: Black Caviar retires after 25 wins
item.description: Unbeaten Australian mare Black Caviar is to be retired after winning 25 consecutive races during a four-year career.

item.title: Bolt to compete in Anniversary Games
item.description: Usain Bolt will compete in the London 2012 Anniversary Games in July along with 28 other Olympic medallists.

item.title: Mark Allen has no regrets
item.description: Mark Allen talks about his controversial past, fears for the sport - and why snooker players are too nice

item.title: Alec Stewart answers your questions
item.description: The ex-England captain on Chris Tremlett's Ashes chances, Gilchrist the great and imaginary fisticuffs with Michael Atherton

item.title: Pinewood studio expands into China
item.description: British film studio Pinewood Shepperton agrees a joint venture deal with Chinese media group Seven Stars to investigate ways to harness the growing entertainment market there.

item.title: Burberry shares up on better sales
item.description: Shares in Burberry rise as much as 8% after the fashion house calms worries about slowing demand in China by posting better-than-forecast results.

item.title: In pictures: Baroness Thatcher's funeral
item.description: Dignitaries from across the world gather in London for the funeral of former UK Prime Minister Baroness Thatcher.

item.title: Thatcher 'force for good', says PM
item.description: David Cameron speaks of his personal debt to Lady Thatcher, on the day of her funeral ceremony, saying she inspired him to become a Conservative in the 1980s.

item.title: Prostate cancer call over men in 40s
item.description: Men should be offered a screening test for prostate cancer in their mid- to late-40s, researchers say.

item.title: 'Bed-of-needles' super-grip plaster
item.description: Scientists have designed a super-grip sticking plaster covered with microscopic needles to heal surgical wounds.

item.title: Teachers' performance pay guidelines
item.description: Pupils' progress and behaviour are to be used to assess teachers for performance pay, in guidance sent to schools.

item.title: Business concerns over curriculum
item.description: The CBI claims the "sheer scale of prescription" in the new science curriculum will leave pupils in England little time for practical experiments.

item.title: Microsoft signs Foxconn patent deal
item.description: Taiwanese electronics assembly giant Hon Hai - owner of Foxconn - agrees to pay Microsoft a patent fee for devices made running Google's operating systems.

item.title: Pirate Bay founder faces new charges
item.description: The co-founder of The Pirate Bay has been charged with stealing data from companies, including a bank.

item.title: Lead threat grows for rare US birds
item.description: One of the rarest US birds is under a growing threat from ingesting lead fragments.

item.title: Physicist's atom struggles revealed
item.description: Letters from famed physicist Niels Bohr to his fiancee during his time in England are revealed to the public at the American Physical Society meeting.

item.title: Emeli Sande up for two Novellos
item.description: Double Brit winner Emeli Sande could be in line for further accolades, having been nominated for two prizes at next month's Ivor Novello awards.

item.title: Family Guy's marathon episode pulled
item.description: Fox pulls a recent episode of the show from its websites that depicted people being run over by a car at the Boston Marathon.

item.title: Charlie does surf
item.description: How the filming of Apocalypse Now accidentally gave rise to surfing culture in the Philippines.

item.title: Thatcher funeral: Can police stop protests?
item.description: What are the laws that will be in force relating to protest during the funeral of Baroness Thatcher?

item.title: Car park death mum 'cared too much'
item.description: A pregnant woman who fell to her death on the day her three children were found dead was sometimes overwhelmed by life, her family say.

item.title: Two arrested over shooting at party
item.description: Two people are arrested after a man was shot in the head at a party in south London and died.

item.title: Salmond attends Thatcher funeral
item.description: Scotland's First Minister Alex Salmond was among more than 2,000 guests who attended the funeral of Baroness Thatcher.

item.title: Scientist jailed for faking tests
item.description: A scientist who faked research data for experimental anti-cancer drugs is the first person in the UK to be jailed under scientific safety laws.

item.title: NI guests attend Thatcher funeral
item.description: First Minister Peter Robinson and a number of other guests from Northern Ireland are attending the funeral of Baroness Thatcher in London.

item.title: Abortion 'may have saved Savita'
item.description: An expert witness tells the Savita Halappanavar inquest that she may have survived if her pregnancy had been terminated days before her death, but it was not a legal option as her life was not at risk at that stage.

item.title: Welsh Guards escort Thatcher coffin
item.description: Two Welsh Guardsmen and Falklands veteran brothers command the pallbearers at the funeral procession of former Prime Minister Baroness Thatcher.

item.title: Cardiff fans celebrate promotion
item.description: Cardiff City fans are celebrating the club winning promotion to the Premier League for the first time after a home draw gives them the point they need.

item.title: Kenya children buried in landslide
item.description: Two children are trapped after a landslide buried their house following heavy rains in western Kenya, the police tell the BBC.

item.title: Ivory Coast want surveillance drones
item.description: Ivory Coast ask the UN for drones to monitor its border with Liberia, as the number of military personnel in the region are reduced.

item.title: Pakistan troops help quake rescue
item.description: Pakistan sends troops to help its citizens affected by a deadly 7.8-magnitude earthquake that struck just over the border in Iran.

item.title: Taiwan runs live-fire military drill
item.description: Taiwan holds its first live-fire military drill since 2008, simulating a Chinese attack on its Penghu Islands.

item.title: Russian activist Navalny on trial
item.description: A judge opens and adjourns an embezzlement case against Russian opposition activist Alexei Navalny, who says the charge is "fabricated" by the state.

item.title: France breast implants trial begins
item.description: Five executives of PIP, the company that sold faulty breast implants, go on trial for fraud in the French city of Marseille.

item.title: Venezuela opposition calls off rally
item.description: Venezuela's opposition leader calls off a rally to demand a recount of Sunday's disputed presidential election, after seven die in clashes.

item.title: Colombia seizes drug lord's villas
item.description: Properties and goods worth more than $25m (£16m) belonging to notorious Colombian drug lord Madman Barrera are seized in a police operation.

item.title: Rockets hit Israeli city of Eilat
item.description: Two rockets fired from the Egyptian Sinai have landed in the southern Israeli city of Eilat without causing damage or injury, police say.

item.title: 'Tear gas fired' at Bahrain school
item.description: Police in Bahrain fire tear gas and clash with students in a raid on a secondary school in the capital, Manama, reports say.

item.title: Computer chaos for American Airlines
item.description: American Airlines grounds all flights across the US for several hours due to a fault with its computerised reservation system.

item.title: US court hears gene patents case
item.description: The US Supreme Court hears arguments questioning whether the human genome can be claimed as intellectual property.

item.title: Day in pictures: 16 April 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 16 April

item.title: In pictures: Boston Marathon explosions
item.description: Two deadly bombs strike in Boston

item.title: In pictures: Royal Yacht Britannia at 60
item.description: A look back at the Royal Yacht Britannia

item.title: In pictures: N Korea celebrations
item.description: 101st anniversary of the birth of Kim Il-sung

item.title: In Pictures: Thatcher funeral rehearsal
item.description: Military rehearsal for Baroness Thatcher

item.title: Chris Bracey: Heaven and Hell
item.description: Light artist's first UK solo exhibition

item.title: Day in pictures: 15 April 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 15 April

item.title: In pictures: Mogadishu court attack
item.description: Attack on the main court buildings in Mogadishu

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: MPs back the government and overturn Lords defeats on shares-for-rights and planning reform.

item.title: VIDEO: Radcliffe on Boston Marathon blasts
item.description: The women's marathon world record-holder Paula Radcliffe has spoken of her "sadness and anger" at an attack on the Boston Marathon which left three people dead and more than 170 injured.

item.title: VIDEO: Boston vigil for bomb victims
item.description: A candlelit vigil has been held in Boston to show sympathy for those killed and injured in blasts at the finish line of the Boston marathon on Monday.

item.title: VIDEO: Testing the science of beauty products
item.description: Lara Lewington talks to cosmetic firms keen to show there really is science behind the beauty claims.

item.title: VIDEO: Fans celebrate Cardiff City's promotion
item.description: Cardiff City fans are celebrating after the club won promotion to the Premier League.

item.title: VIDEO: Tiny alleyway gets double yellow lines
item.description: An alleyway, which would not accommodate even the smallest car, has been painted with double yellow lines.

item.title: VIDEO: India's deadly unsafe abortions
item.description: Sanjoy Majumder reports on the alarmingly large number of women who die in India because of unsafe abortions.

item.title: VIDEO: Israel at 65: Life in a yeshiva
item.description: BBC reporter John Ware visits Israel's ultra-Orthodox Jewish community and is given a rare glimpse inside a yeshiva (religious) school

item.title: VIDEO: Iran struck by major earthquake
item.description: Iran has been struck by its most powerful earthquake for more than 50 years, with tremors felt across Pakistan, India and the Middle East.

item.title: The art of hand crafted bicycles
item.description: The art and craft of creating bespoke bicycles

item.title: Mexico's vigilante law enforcers
item.description: The Mexican town that gave up relying on the police

item.title: Walking in Graham Greene's footsteps
item.description: Retracing Graham Greene's footsteps to a sacred waterfall

item.title: 7 questions on double yellow lines
item.description: Test yourself on road marking rules

item.title: Atkins and the never-ending battle over carbs
item.description: Do all the carb-haters have a valid point?

item.title: Can UK firms make it in the US?
item.description: Why is the US market so hard to crack for British firms?

item.title: Applicants wanted: One-way ticket to Mars
item.description: Would you apply for a one-way ticket to the Red Planet

item.title: John Legend talks 'Love In The Future'
item.description: John Legend on love, fidelity, and cheating at Scrabble

item.title: In pictures: Photo Pulitzer Prize Winners
item.description: The 2013 Pulitzer Prize winners for breaking news photography

item.title: Will Tesco be deposed as retail king?
item.description: Will Tesco's withdrawal from US turn things round for it?

item.title: A changed US reaction to terror
item.description: Mark Mardell detects a different US reaction to the one after 9/11
